item.title: Report I-2025010003
item.description:
Report I-2025010003

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-15T00:55:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-29
  • City: SEADRIFT
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: DOW Chemical-Watco Yard
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 11/29/24 at approximately 23:00 conductor notified !he yardmaster on duty that they had located a leaking Anhydrous Ammonia rail car, STPX 220216. Yardmaster immediately had the crew clear the area and escalated to DOW EH&S who responded and attempted to secure the car and stop the leak. EH&S was unable to stop the leak and Specialized Response Solutions was contacted for remediation. SRS arrived on scene and began to work on the leak. The vapor valve was found to be leaking through the bonnet and the secondary closure plug after being unloaded and moved to a storage yard. Dow's Emergency Response Team responded and attempted to repair the leak by tightening the valve handle but found that the handle was stripped. The valve handle was removed to be replaced by another valve handle. After removal of the stripped handle the valve stem was found to be rounded off. This prevented the addition of closure pressure without gouging the valve shaft. The response team used a 24-inch pipe wrench and was able to apply a small amount of force that only minimally affected the leak volume through the bonnet. The Dow ER team was considering installing the Midland Emergency Response Kit (ERK) but the protective housing only had three port holes therefore the capping kit strongback would not connect properly. SRS crew returns to the tank car to construct and install a vapor scrubber and install a containment bag over the vapor valve. The internal pressure of the car is approximately 85 psig. The two-tote vapor scrubber is set up and operational. While the crew was preparing to place a containment bag over the vapor valve the decision was made to loosen the valve faceplate and release the pressure contained in the body of the valve. This would simplify the installation of the containment bag over the vapor valve. Crew removes the vapor valve faceplate. Minimal pressure is heard leaking through the sealing surface of the valve. The crew find that the seat disc (gasket) installed in the seat disc retainer assembly has been partially dislodged. The seat disc has been crushed by force being applied to the valve stem. Without removal of all pressure from the tank car the leak would not be repaired Crew attempted to install the capping kit gasket between the vapor valve and the magnetic gauging rod flange assembly. Although the gasket would not fit the crew decided to shave the side of the gasket and try again with no success. Decision made to remove the magnetic gauging rod flange and shave one quarter inch off the edge of the flange facing the vapor valve. The nuts securing the protective housing outer ring are removed and the outer ring is rotated 90 degrees to provide port holes for the capping kit strong back. Midland capping kit is successfully installed. As pressure in the can increases the pressure is sent to the scrubber while seating the gasket confirming containment. This is being done due to the defective sealing surface and corrosion on the surface of the

item.title: Report E-2025020131
item.description:
Report E-2025020131

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-13T06:18:15+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-10
  • City: MARBLE FALLS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On February 10, 2025, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN3267 was punctured and released approximately one (1) gallon to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the site. The crew utilized neutralizers and absorbents to remediate the site. All waste and the damaged pail were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum.

item.title: Report I-2025010078
item.description:
Report I-2025010078

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-13T06:18:15+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-18
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: PORT TERMINAL RAILROAD ASSOCIATION (INC)
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At approximately 7:34 PM on 01/18/25 oit was reported that tank car CGTX 31196 was leaking when the car was moved, the car was isolated in our track 48 at North Yard until we could contact the shipper. The shipper was contacted on 01/19/25 and requested we use pur Haz-Mat Contractor Haz-Mat Special Services to repair and clean. They determined that the swing bolts were not tightened properly resulting the leak, they corrected the issues and cleaned the car.

item.title: Report I-2025010076
item.description:
Report I-2025010076

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-13T06:18:15+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-16
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Port Terminal Railroad Association
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Car was being inspected by FRA Inspector who contacted me about the contents leaking and I immediately engaged our Haz-Mat Contractor to respond to the scene. The car was leaking from under the dome lid due to four of the six swing bolts on the manway lid being less than tool-tight, our contractor was able to correct the issue and stop the leak.

item.title: Report I-2025010075
item.description:
Report I-2025010075

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-13T06:18:15+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-16
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Car was being inspected by FRA Inspector who contacted me about the contents leaking and I immediately engaged our Haz-Mat Contractor to respond to the scene. The car was leaking from under the dome lid due to the Vapor Valve Line being wide open with the cap not applied, our contractor was able to correct the issue and stop the leak.

item.title: Report I-2025010022
item.description:
Report I-2025010022

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-13T06:18:15+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-09
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: PORT TERMINAL RAILROAD ASSOCIATION (INC)
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At approximately 8:00 PM on 01/09/25 our switch crew reported an odor while switch with car CCBX 2430, at the time of the report it was raining heavily and no leak could be detected, the car was isolated in our track 1 at North Yard until we could inspect this morning on 01/10/25 when it quit raining. A small amount of product was detected on the side of the car under the platform grating as was as along the lip of the Multi-Housing Nozzle and cover. The shipper Dow/R&H was notified and dispatched SRS along with their plant personnel to inspect the car and reported that the O-Ring on the magnetic gauge device had broken in two and that is what caused the release. The O-Ring was replaced and the car was cleaned of any residue.
